raw_text:
US actor 'found with gun residue'
 
 Actor Robert Blake had gunshot residue on his hands and clothes the night his wife was shot dead, a court has heard.
 
 But it may not have come from the shot that killed Bonny Lee Bakley in 2001, Mr Blake's murder trial was told by criminalist Steven Dowell. Mr Dowell told a Los Angeles court the residue may have come from Mr Blake's revolver, his gun collection, his presence at the crime scene or police. The 71-year-old former star of US TV drama Baretta has denied murder. Mr Blake said he found Ms Bakley, 44, dead in a car after they left a restaurant.
 
 He said he briefly returned to the restaurant to collect a gun he had left behind and discovered her body when he returned. The gun he collected was not the murder weapon. It could also have been picked up if he touched or leant on the car when he found the body, or from a police box in which his clothes were later stored. The box had come from an area where officers went after being on the firing range. But Mr Dowell also said the residue would have been present if Mr Blake fired a gun that night. Witnesses have already told the trial Mr Blake "stood out as being quite nervous and agitated" at the restaurant before the murder. The actor, who won an Emmy for playing a maverick detective in the 1970s TV cop drama Baretta, could face life in prison if convicted.
llama3.2:1b: Robert Blake, a US actor, has gunshot residue on his hands and clothes from a night when his wife Bonny Lee Bakley was shot dead. The police found the gun he used to collect was not the murder weapon, but it could have been picked up by him or touched while standing near the crime scene. Blake denies murder and claims the gun he collected may have come from a different incident or even a police box where his clothes were stored before the incident. He also stood out as being nervous and agitated in the restaurant where the shooting occurred.
llama3.2:3b: Actor Robert Blake had gunshot residue on his hands and clothes after his wife was shot dead in 2001, possibly from his own gun, police presence, or being at the crime scene.

He claims he found her body after a brief trip back to the restaurant to collect a gun he had left behind. The gun in question was not the murder weapon. Other possibilities include touching or leaning on the car where she was discovered or from a police box where his clothes were later stored.

The 71-year-old former star of the TV drama Baretta denied murder, while Mr Blake said he found Ms Bakley dead in a car after they left a restaurant. He briefly returned to collect a gun left behind and discovered her body when he returned. The gun could also have been picked up from the police box in which his clothes were later stored. Witness accounts say Mr Blake was nervous and agitated at the restaurant before the murder, which led him to believe "stood out as being quite nervous and agitated" at the restaurant before the murder.

Blake denies murder, claiming he found his wife in a car and collected her body's gun because he had left it behind earlier. Witnesses reported Blake as nervous and agitated before the incident. If convicted, Blake faces potential life imprisonment.
opencoder:1.5b: US actor 'found with gun residue' - A former US star found with gunshot residue on his hands and clothes after they were shot dead. The murder was committed by Robert Blake, who used a revolver to commit the crime. He was charged with murder, 71-year-old Bakley's death was announced, and police have released information suggesting the residue may have come from his Revolver or his gun collection. Mr Dowell further hinted at other possibilities, including his presence at the scene or police presence. The suspect is former US TV drama host Baretta, who had previously denied murder.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and to the point, preserving the key ideas and details of the original text. It does not provide explanations or justifications for the claims made by the author. The summary only presents the main points and does not add any new information or insights.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text concisely while preserving key ideas and details. Let's see... 

First, the main characters are Robert Blake and Bonny Lee Bakley. I remember Blake was an actor who starved for a TV show called Baretta. He had some gun residue near his body when she died, but the exact source isn't clear because there could be multiple possibilities. The court is hearing about this.

Steven Dowell, a criminalist, testified about it saying that the residue might come from Blake's revolver, his collection, or where he was when he found the body. He mentioned it could also be picked up if he touched the car, so maybe another person's property. Plus, there was a box in his clothes that he stored, and Dowell said even if he fired a gun that night, the residue might still be there.

Blake denied murder and stated he found Bakley in a car after the dinner but only returned to collect a gun he had left behind. That gun wasn't the murder weapon. He could have gotten it elsewhere too. Witnesses at the scene described Blake as nervous and angry, so maybe that played a role in his testimony.

The trial is facing possible life in prison if he's convicted because of this DNA evidence linking him to Bakley. So, I need to put all these points into a concise summary without explanations or formatting.
</think>

Robert Blake, an actor from Baretta TV cop drama, had gun residue near his body when Bonny Lee Bakley died. The residue could come from Blake's revolver, his collection, where he was at the scene, or a box in his clothes stored later.criminalist Steven Dowell testified that the residue might be there if Blake fired a night's gun, and witnesses described Blake as nervous. The trial faces possible life in prison for this DNA evidence linking him to Bakley.
tinyllama:1.1b: Los Angeles Court: Robert Blake had gun residue on his hands and clothes when he was charged with killing Bonny Lee Bakley in 2001. However, it may have come from the murder weapon or from police equipment, as Mr Blake claimed that he found Ms Bakley dead after returning to the restaurant from a dinner date and discovered her body by chance. Witnesses have stated that Mr Blake "stood out as being quite nervous" and "agitated" when he arrived at the restaurant before the murder. The trial is expected to last several weeks, with further evidence on the reliability of gun residue and witness testimony being presented. If found guilty, Mr Blake could face life imprisonment.
